body:
Patricia of Naples

From Wikipedia, the free encyclopedia
Jump to navigation Jump to search
Saint Patricia of Naples
Born seventh century
Constantinople
Died ~665 AD
Naples
Venerated in Roman Catholic Church
Feast August 25
Patronage Naples (co-patron)

Saint Patricia of Naples (or Patricia of Constantinople ) ( Italian : Santa Patrizia ) (died ca. 665 AD) is an Italian virgin and saint . Tradition states that she was noble; she may have been related to the Roman Emperor . Some sources say that she was a descendant of Constantine the Great . [1] The particulars traditional about her are unreliable and in some instances contradictory. [2]

Wishing to escape a marriage arranged by Constans II and become a nun , she went to Rome . There she received the veil from Pope Liberius . Upon the death of her father, she returned to Constantinople and, renouncing any claim to the imperial crown, distributed her wealth to the poor. She then planned to go on pilgrimage to Jerusalem .

However, a terrible storm shipwrecked her on the shores of Naples . Finding refuge on the tiny island of Megarides (the site of the present-day Castel dell'Ovo ), the site of a small hermitage , Patricia died shortly after from disease.

Veneration [ edit ]

The monastery of Sante Patricia contained her relics . During the turbulent events of 1864, they were translated to the monastery of San Gregorio Armeno . Covered in wax , her relics were contained in an urn of gold, gems, and silver, and were placed in the monastery’s chapel. The monastery also preserves her blood. [3] Her blood, like that of Januarius , the other, more famous patron saint of Naples, is also said to liquefy periodically. [1] The associated legend states that after Patricia died, a zealous man pulled out one of her teeth, causing the body to hemorrhage . Patricia's followers collected the blood and exposed it. It then liquefied. Her blood is said to turn to liquid on her feast day of August 25th, and on every Tuesday morning. [4]

Notes [ edit ]

  1. ^ a b Borelli, Antonio. "Santa Patrizia di Costantinopoli", Santi e Beati, August 27, 2015
  2. ^ Monks of Ramsgate. “Patritia”. Book of Saints , 1921. CatholicSaints.Info. 17 August 2016.
  3. ^ Urbs Sanguinum - Santa Patrizia Archived 2007-06-30 at the Wayback Machine
  4. ^ http://www.turismoregionecampania.it/allegati/filiere/en/Guida_Religiosa_en.pdf [ permanent dead link ]

External links [ edit ]

  • (in Italian) Santa Patrizia di Costantinopoli
  • Saint Patricia of Naples at Patron Saints Index
  • (in Italian) Puppet show in honor of Saint Patricia
